Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Propofol in Pediatric Anesthesia

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted in pediatric anesthesia settings.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were children undergoing surgical procedures requiring anesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received propofol, while the control group received an alternative anesthetic.

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to assess the influence of propofol on pediatric anesthesia pharmacology.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the depth of anesthesia, assessed using EEG signals over a 24-hour period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean difference in depth of anesthesia was 5.2 units (95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects reported.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
